content: Theimine-linked cage NC1 wassynthesized byaconden-sation reaction between 3,3 ¡¯,5,5 ¡¯-tetraformyl-4,4 ¡¯-biphenyldioland (1R,2R)/(1S,2S)-1,2-diaminoc yclohexane ina[3++6]cycloimination viaa¡°mixandmatch¡± approach (see Sup-porting Information fordetailed experimental data). Thecrystal structure ofNC1 shows triangular prism configurationwhich issimilar tothatofracemic TCC1 cage without hydroxygroups both inwindow sizeandcage shape .[12]Itisinterestingthat addition ofhydroxy groups does notlead toatotallydifferent structure ,which may allow fortheintroduction ofsome other functional groups without altering the[3++6]cageconfiguration. Synthesis of NC1 . NC1 was prepared by using a ¡°mix and match¡± strategy. First ly, equal amount s of two enantiomer ic cages were  prepared , respectively.  3,3',5,5' - Tetraformyl -4,4'-biphenyldiol ( 120 mg, 0.40 mmol ) was dissolved in DMF (80  mL) and stirred for dissolution at 110 ¡ãC. A methan ol (40 mL)  solution of (1R,2R)/(1S,2S)-1,2-diaminocyclohexane  (92 mg, 0.80 mmol) and an aqueous solution of hydrochloric acid  (8 mL, 0.12 mol/L) were added into the mixture, and t he red solution was refluxed overnight. Second ly, two opposite chiral enantiomer ic solution s were mixed quickly. The resulting mixture was left for slow evaporation in air at room temperature about  2 ~ 3  days. Finally,  red single crystal s of NC1 suitable for X -ray diffraction  determination were collect ed in a yield of 200 m g. The desolvate d sample  of NC1  was obtained by super -critical carbon dioxide (SCD)  activation  for the following conventional characterizations . 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3, TMS,  ppm) ¦Ä 14.09 (s, OH, 6H), 8.52 (s, 12H), 8.15 (s, 6H), 7.63 (s, 6H), 3.46 (s, CHN, 6H), 3.15 (s, CHN, 6H), 2.06 ~ 1.25 (m, CH 2, 48H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl 3, TMS,  ppm) ¦Ä 165.30, 162.03, 158.18, 129.35, 126.49, 124.93, 123.86, 118.51, 74.68, 72.35, 32.49, 31.69, 29.86, 24.31.  FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1) ¦Í 3436 (m), 2931 (s), 2860 (m), 1641 (s), 1599 (m), 1450 (s), 1381 (w), 1346 (w), 1290 (w), 1259 (w), 1145 (w), 1101 (w), 1062 (w), 1010 (w), 981 (w), 939 (w), 869 (w), 846 (w), 763 (w).

Synthesis of Na -NC1 . NC1 (120 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of 1,4-dioxane and DMF (50 mL  : 20 mL) at 100 ¡ãC, and an aqueous  solution  (~2 mL) of NaN 3 (52 mg, 0,80 mmol)  was added after 10 minutes . The red solution was refluxed overnight, cooled, filtered, and left for slow evaporation in air at room temperature for 2 weeks . Red single crystal s of Na -NC1 suitable for X -ray diffraction  determination were collect ed in a yield of 40 m g. The desolvate d sample  of Na-NC1  was obtained by super -critical carbon dioxide (SCD)  activation  for the following conventional characterizations.  1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3, TMS,  ppm) ¦Ä 14.06 (s, 6H), 8.53 (s, 6H), 8.37 (s, 6H), 8.03 (s, 6H), 7.46 (s, 6H), 3.49 (s, 6H), 3.19 (s, 6H), 4   1.26 ¨C 2.10 (m, 48H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl 3, TMS,  ppm) ¦Ä 165.24, 161.83, 158.21, 129.44, 126.49, 124.90, 123.84, 118.12, 74.61, 72.85, 32.25, 31.72, 29.71 , 24.19. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1) ¦Í 3429 (m), 2933 (s), 2860 (s), 1639 (s), 1600 (m), 1448 (s), 1382 (m), 1346 (w), 1292 (w), 1259 (m), 1143 (w), 1099 (w), 1010 (m), 977 (w), 941 (w), 871 (w), 765 (w), 680 (w).

NC1 and Na-NC1 canbedesolvated byusing super -critical carbon dioxide activation toyield guest-free poroussolids foradsorption-desorption measurements (See Support-ingInformation Section S4). NC1 shows type IN2sorptionbehavior with acorresponding BET surface area of802m2g/C01(Langmuir surface area 891m2g/C01)at77K(Figure 2a),whichisclose tothat oftheracemic cage TCC1[12](881 m2g/C01).Incontrast, Na-NC1 displays non-porous towards N2at77K,which may beattributed totwopossible reasons :OneisthatN2isadiatomic molecule with aquadrupole moment whichproduces specific interactions atthegas¨Csolid interface ,andtheother isthatN2molecules may have adiffusion problemwithin thepores at77K.[17]Asanalternate ,argon isused astheprobe molecule toobtain thesorption-desorption iso-therm, andNa-NC1 exhibits atypeIAradsorption isothermwith aBETsurface area of1230 m2g/C01(Langmuir surfacearea 1670 m2g/C01)at87K(Figure 2b).Thisvalue could bealsosupported byCO2adsorption isotherm at196K,wheresimilar BET surface areas of1219 and 1218 m2g/C01areobtained byusing BET andt-plot methods ,respectively (seeSection S6).Theexperimental BET surface area ofNa-NC1 islower than itssimulated oneat1741 m2g/C01(see Section S6).
